results.title: Sirens
results.creator_credit: British Screen Finance Limited, Samson Productions, WMG Film, Sarah Radclyffe Productions-Sirens Limited, Sue Milliken and John Duigan
results.brief_description: Set in a small Australian town in the 1920s, “Sirens” is a light-hearted comedy written and directed by John Duigan (Flirting, The Year my voice broke). It is the (fictional) story of Australian artist Norman Lindsay (Sam Neill) who has raised the ire of the Church, with his erotically charged depictions of nude women. The Church regards his art as sinful, blasphemous and morally damaging. Lindsay is living on a large property in bohemian bliss with his wife (Pamela Rabe), children and models. An English preacher Anthony Campion (Hugh Grant) is sent to Lindsay’s property to try to dissuade him from continuing to paint and draw in his current style. Campion’s wife Estella (Tara Fitzgerald), who accompanies Anthony on this trip, is sexually frustrated and bored with her marriage. The sirens of the title (Elle Macpherson, Portia de Rossi and Kate Fischer) cavort semi-clad for much of their time at the artist’s house and studio, causing the sexual tension between Anthony and Estella, to rise. Estella experiences extensive erotic dreams featuring the sirens and various men she has encountered. “Sirens” features a famed scene where the five main women of the film are shown naked atop a mountain range. An Australian/United Kingdom co-production, also starring Ben Mendelsohn and John Polson.

results.title: Singin' in the rain [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Arthur Freed, Gene Kelly and Stanley Donen
results.brief_description: The seemingly eternal freshness of “Singin’ in the rain” may be the result of an unusual degree of improvisation involved in its making. More than most musicals this was a team effort - a coming together of talents striving to overcome the limitations that they saw in the material and given space in which to move. In the process they not only produced one of the finest of movie musicals but also one of the best Hollywood-on-Hollywood movies - an intelligent and affectionate satire on the coming of synchronised sound. It is also a high point of what Richard Dyer calls the Utopian musical of the fifties which erased the distinction between the narrative and the musical numbers, the ultimate management of the contradiction between realism and fantasy inherent in the genre. Features catchy tunes, lively choreography with the athletic grace and Irish charm of Gene Kelly, engaging performances and hilarious jokes. Gene Kelly was co-director, choreographer and actor in this spectacular musical and in 1989 it was one of the first twenty-five films selected by the US Library of Congress for its National Film Registry of significant films.

results.title: Silverado [DVD]
results.brief_description: Silverado is an old west frontier town in the evil grip of a corrupt and powerful, smiling-viper sheriff (Brian Dennehy). But things are about to change around town. Four unlikely heroes - brothers Emmett (Scott Glenn) and Jake (Kevin Costner), adventurer Paden (Kevin Kline), and a crack-shot negro cowboy (Danny Glover)- saddle up for a series of dangerous adventures on the dusty trail to Silverado. From its explosive, breathtaking opening gun battle to a final, tense high-noon shoot-out, this thrilling, hell-for-leather western is bursting with spectacular action. This is director Kasdan’s tribute to the great and much-loved tradition of the Wild West.

results.title: Silkwood
results.brief_description: On November 13,1974, Karen Silkwood, an employee of a nuclear plant, left to meet with a reporter from the New York Times. She was trying to expose the dangers of radiation in the plant. She died in a mysterious car crash on the way. Meryl Streep stars in this story of the events leading up to her death.

results.title: Sick: the life and death of Bob Flanagan, supermasochist (D)
results.brief_description: The title of this powerful documentary about performance artist and cystic fibrosis sufferer Bob Flanagan hits the mark on two levels. In one sense, it describes his physical condition; Flanagan suffered from the disease all his life and died from it at 43. The second, more evocative reference is to the shockingly direct sadomasochism of the artist’s performances. This is not a film for the squeamish, the prudish, or the faint-hearted. Even hardened viewers may feel disconcerted by Flanagan’s performances, which include piercing and penetrating of almost every body part by practically any sharp object. No other artist in history has examined so literally the experience of pain and the associated pleasures of sadomasochism and domination. Dick was also able to record a great deal of the last two years of Flanagan’s life, including his death, creating as comprehensive a portrait of an artist and his work as possible. (Awards: Winner of the Special Artistic Merit Award, Sundance, 1997).

results.title: Siam sunset
results.creator_credit: Film Finance Corporation Australia, New South Wales Film and Television Office, Artist Services, South Australian Film Corporation, Al Clark and John Polson
results.brief_description: After his wife is killed in a freak accident involving a falling refrigerator, British industrial chemist Perry (Linus Roache) travels to Australia to escape and in search of an elusive paint colour after seeing a photo of the Australian outback in a travel brochure. He joins the budget price Whippet tour bus, a motley crew of travellers that includes an aspiring country and western singer, bickering couples, and a woman (Danielle Cormack) fleeing her violent, drug dealing boyfriend whose money she has stolen. Disaster follows Perry everywhere and Australia is no exception: earth tremors, a deceased roadside trader, inclement weather, a dangerous ex-boyfriend and New Year’s Eve at a roadhouse in the middle of nowhere after their bus crashes. A humorous coach war between the Whippet driver determined to out drive a competing driver of a swish coach also travelling to Darwin provides a highlight of the film, as is the Australian outback. Cast also includes: Ian Bliss, Roy Billing, Alan Brough, Rebecca Hobbs, Esme Melville.

results.title: Show me love = F*****g Amal
results.creator_credit: Memphis Films, Peter Aalbaek Jensen, Lars Jonsson and Lukas Moodysson
results.brief_description: This insightful and realistic film about teenage sexuality is set in a small Swedish town. Elin (Alexandra Dahlstrom) is beautiful and popular but the limitations of a small town lead her to increasing experimentation with alcohol, sex and drugs. Agnes (Reecca Liljeberg) is finding that after nearly two years in her new high school she is still largely friendless and alone. Elin and Agnes inhabit two very different social worlds but when they do finally meet they discover a disturbing and exciting sexual attraction for each other. Elin deals with this knowledge by throwing herself into a relationship with a shy diffident boy (Mathias Rust) while Agnes increasingly becomes to accept her lesbianism. “Show Me Love” is replete with incidents and moments that resonate with the confusions and tensions of adolescence. Refusing easy moralism or neat conclusions, Lukas Moodysson crafts an intelligent examination of contemporary youth culture. This is a gritty love story tenderly and convincingly performed by its young cast. In Swedish with English subtitles.

results.title: Shoot the piano player = Tirez sur le pianiste [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Films de la Pleiade, Pierre Braunberger and Francois Truffaut
results.brief_description: After his deeply personal autobiographical debut, “The 400 Blows”, Truffaut’s second feature was a homage to film noir and gangster films. But unlike the strict genre rules of the Hollywood films, “Shoot the Piano Player” is as much a celebration of the pleasure and possibilities of cinema as it is a straightforward crime film. Peppered with comic asides, philosophical speculations, and dissertations on love, it is beautifully shot in black and white by Raoul Coutard and features a jazzy score by George Delerue (both cinematographer and composer were to have a longstanding collaboration with Truffaut). Based on a crime novel, “Down There” by David Goodis, the film stars Charles Aznavour who is convincingly seedy and attractive as a once famous classical pianist, Edouard Saroyan, who has abandoned fame and his career after the tragic death of his wife. His anonymity is shattered when his brother runs into him one night in a cafe. The brother is being pursued by two thugs who are after the loot Edouard’s older brothers have run off with after double-crossing the two thugs during a bank robbery. Wanting to protect his brothers, Edouard goes to their rescue, realising that it is his fate to have security, love and peace always snatched from him. On its release, “Shoot the Piano Player” cemented Truffaut’s reputation as one of the leading filmmakers in the French New Wave, the movement which was to influence and vitalise filmmakers across generations and across the globe. More humanistic and more playful than his groundbreaking colleague, Jean-Luc Godard, “Shoot the Piano Player” still astonishes with its wit, speed and irreverent spirit. Truffaut was to follow this film with “Jules et Jim” in 1961, ensuring that his first three films make for one of the most dazzling “adolescence” in movie history. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Shock to the system
results.creator_credit: Corsair Pictures, Patrick McCormick and Jan Egleson
results.brief_description: Graham Marshall (Michael Caine) is a middle-aged New York advertising exec recently passed over in a sure fire promotion to a younger subordinate (Peter Riegert). Suffering the effects of this crushing oversight, Graham inadvertently pushes a panhandler into the oncoming path of a subway train, killing the man instantly. Charged with murder, Graham is released on manslaughter. This leads him to speculate on the possibility of repeating his actions - murder, camouflaged as accident - and plots to get back at some of his enemies, starting at home with his shrewish wife (Swoosie Kurtz). The downtrodden suit has turned into a likeable avenger. This parable of corporate greed in post 1980s Wall Street is a curious mix of thriller and black comedy. Cast also includes Will Patton as the obligatory gumshoe and Elizabeth McGovern as the sympathetic co-worker and love interest. Based on the novel by Simon Brett.

Cast also includes Will Patton as the obligatory gumshoe and Elizabeth McGovern as the sympathetic co-worker and love interest. Based on the novel by Simon Brett.
